div1.head: Report on the Probable Origin of the Epidemic of Yellow Fever, by Bauvallet, August 25, 1922
div1.p:
REPORT ON THE PROBABLE ORIGIN OF THE EPIDEMIC
OF YELLOW FEVER.

As early as June 26 we pointed out by T-o-v-p-33-H that there
was at least one case of yellow fever in Dahomey. On June 27 we con-
firm this by t-o-34-H, giving the information furnished us by the
physician of Kouroussa.

On the 28th we sent out Circular 35-H, in which we warned
the population that all infractions of our orders concerning stagnant
water would be punished. The same day our service orders to the
Adjutant, chief technical agent of the Sanitary Service, defined the
measures to be taken.

On the same day, the Chief Physician, Head of the Health
Service of the Ivory Coast, arrived at our request to examine a patient
on the Steamship “New Georgia” which had arrived from the south. The
patient V., was found to be suffering from malaria. The ship remained
in port 18 days, had no more cases of illness, and was recognized to be
free from Stegomyia.

We kept all arrivals from the south under careful surveillance.
As a result we discovered on board the S.S. “Barracoo” on July 28 some
sick persons whose illness we diagnosed as malaria, one of the cases
being serious. On the 29th we received the t-o 92 S.S. pointing out
a caso of yellow fever at Accra and ordering that all arrivals from the
Gold Coast be kept under observation.

On the 31st occurred the death of the very sick patient on the
“Barracoo”, a ship-boy of 14. Our diagnosis on August 1, after autopsy,
was that the patient died of pernicious attack. The body showed no
appreciable icterus, no sanguineous diffusion, and no trace of blood in
the abdominal cavity. Besides, the ship had stayed from June 29 to
July 23, at Lagos, where the work was very hard, and it had many patients.

In spite of the advice of the ship's officers, the sailors
wore no helmets and took no quinine. The ship-boy imitated the rest
and owned no helmet. From July 23 to 26, the date of reaching Bassam,
the “Barracoo” touched at Secondi and Axim, but not at Accra, cast anchor
at sea, and sent no one but the purser ashore (according to the statement of
Captain G. Owen.) to make arrangements for the very small amount of freight
that was to be taken on.

After the examination of the body, the “Barracoo” was thoroughly
inspected and was declared free from Stegomyia. A single Culex Pipiens was
found after a three hours' search. The cargo consisted of wood, cotton,
and palmetto. The ship was regularly disinfected every Monday with creoline.

If the ship had at anytime harbored infected Stegomia, supposing
that the ship-boy's case had been yellow fever, the latter's neighbors would
have been infected, as he passed his entire illness in the sleeping quarters
of the ship, with 10 bunks grouped one above the other, and no mosquito
netting. The ship remained 16 days in Bassam and no other case of fever
occurred.

Sixteen crew-boys Knot from the wharf, who spent the night of July 31-
August 1 transferring the passengers of the “Eleina”, which reached Bassam
about 10 p.m., were kept under observation at the quarantine station for
6 days as a special precautionary measure and were observed for 6 days more.
The agent of the Elder Co., and two passengers of the “Elmina”, who came
from the north and spent the night on board the “Barracoo”, were placed
in “sanitary passports”, None of them revealed any traces of fever.
The death of the ship-boy occurred on the 31st after the closing of the
wharf.

Early in July we turned our attention to the strict super-
vision of the native morbidity and mortality. The Administrator of
Bassam, without whose aid we would not have been able to accomplish
anything, and to whom we wish to express at this point our sincere
thanks, called the native chiefs together and explained to them the
necessity of informing us of the cases of sickness so that we could
take precautionary measures from the first.

The native mortality was 7 in June and 6 in July. There is
absolutely nothing unusual in these figures for a population of over 3000.
The cases were sought out by the sanitary agents in the sections. Secret
agents at France Imperial and Moossou informed us of the very rare cases
that were not reported.
No case could be considered suspicious.

However, we were aware that the danger lay in the direction of
the Gold Coast, and we asked the Chief of the Health Service to watch
the frontier.

Although the sanitary clearance papers were all absolutely
clean even after the telegram from the Governor of the Gold Coast
announcing a case of yellow fever at Accra, we considered the maritime
inspection at Bassam sufficient and efficient. All the native passengers
had since several months been examined on landing and their baggage
disinfected. This measure was applied to ships from every locality
after the past-laden breath from Dakar in August, 1921.

From the land side the situation was uncertain. There was
incessant communication by way of the shore between Bassam, Assinie and
the Gold Coast (one day's journey on foot).

On June 29, Mr. X., who left Afornou on the 28th at 2 A.M.,
by the Accra road, arrives in Bassam, sent there by the chief epidemic
officer in Assinie. He was brought back half dead to Assinie by his men,
and immediately sent on to us in a hammock. Without this accident, his
crossing the frontier would have remained unknown.

He was isolated at once, in coma, at the quarantine station,
or rather in one of the sheds that go by that name. He was found to
be suffering from sunstroke with resulting mental “afusion”, and was
discharged completely cured on July 11.

In July the European morbidity and mortality was normal. There
were two deaths, that of Mr. Y., who was accidentally killed on July 14,
and that of Mr. Z., a naturalized Dahomeyan and a salesman for tree nurseries.
He had received judicial summons, and was found dead on the morning of the
17th. The autopsy, which was performed at the request of the prosecuting
attorney, who suspected suicide, showed lesions of apoplectic icterus. The
stomach, which was kept for the purpose of a possible expert opinion, was
perfectly normal and completely empty. The Court held that the cause of
death was definitely discovered by the autopsy, and did not ask for a
toxicological analysis.

We now come to August 4, the date of the death of Mrs. R., who
was treated at home.

This case is worth discussing. We have already described it
in our 144-S.

The patient took to her bed on July 31, and we saw her in the
course of the forenoon. The anamnesis and the early symptoms were those
of bilious hemoglobinuria. On the third day the urine was decidedly “bitter”.
We noted:

August 3 - anuria, no icterus, epigastralgia, bilious vomit
with no trace of blood.

August 4 - forenoon (7 A.M.) - the patient got up to urinate
and had a fatal syncope.

There was no icterus at the time of placing the body in the
load coffin for transportation to France. Diagnosis: bilious hemo-
globinuria, but with a suspicious epigastralgic symptom. It was im-
possible to make a diagnosis of yellow fever on this epigastralgia; there
was no autopsy.

If this case can be considered suspicious, and we readily admit
it, it must be noted that the persons who surrounded the patient, and her
husband, who slept in the same bed with her until she died, none of them
were infected.

On August 5 our circular 51-H announced the increased severity
of the Sanitary Service. On August 7 we made out 7 summons for Europeans.
The entire week from the 7th to the 12th was marked by an increase in the
number of summons to Europeans and of disciplinary measures for the natives.
The average for the past months is about 40.

Seventeen days after the beginning of the illness of Mrs. R.,
we admitted to the ambulance hospital as an urgent case Mr. E., a resident
at the Hotel Botteleau. He fell ill on the 16th, had an attack of path-
ognomonic black vomit on the 17th at about 5 P.M., and died at 6:45 P.M.
The autopsy, which was made in the forenoon of the 18th, revealed a stomach
full of “coffee grounds”, a chamois-colored liver, and a saffron-yellow skin.
The Chief Physician, to whom we reported the case by a telegram dated the
17th in the evening, came down to Bassam and confirmed the diagnosis by
examination of the pieces.

Mr. E. was absolutely without resources and had arrived in
Bassam some two or three months before, leading a mysterious existence.
He belonged to a crowd composed of a few Italians who had made the
Hotel Botteleau their headquarters. These Italians, who come down
from the Gold Coast to recruit laborers for Secondi and Accra, sometimes
vanish for a week at a time, and Mr. E. did the same.

On august 18, Mr. F., an Italian, fell ill, was isolated in
the quarantine station, and passed through an attenuated but distinct attack
of yellow fever. He was E.'s room-mate and slept in the same bed with him.

Two Italians of the same crowd, and who lived in another house,
were questioned on the order of Mr. Mondon. One of them did not deny
that he was aware of the escapades of E. and F., and said that they could
very well have gone recently to the Gold Coast. The other one refused to
talk.

It is reasonable to suppose that E. and F., when they found
themselves forbidden to do any recruiting, had themselves secretly conducted
men to the Gold Coast. According to all probability they were infected on
the Gold Coast, and this the more easily since they lived in unsanitary
conditions and had no mosquito nets.

We believe that that is where the source of the accidental
center in Bassam is to be found.
